benchmark_details.name: CatShift
benchmark_details.overview: CatShift is a label-only dataset-inference framework that leverages catastrophic forgetting to detect whether a suspicious dataset was used in training a large language model.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To detect unauthorized usage of proprietary datasets using label-only outputs from large language models.
purpose_and_intended_users.limitations: CatShift may struggle with datasets that substantially overlap with other data in the modelâ€™s training corpus.

data.source: Experimental datasets created for evaluating membership in large language models.
data.size: Various sizes depending on subsets analyzed.

methodology.calculation: Comparison of output shifts before and after fine-tuning using a statistical hypothesis test.
methodology.interpretation: Lower p-values indicate a higher likelihood that the suspicious dataset was part of the training data.
methodology.baseline_results: Baseline method achieved an AUC score of 0.707 and F1 score of 0.717; CatShift achieved an AUC score of 0.979 and F1 score of 0.863.
methodology.validation: Statistical tests such as Kolmogorov-Smirnov are employed to validate results.
